targets.Name: Cat
Text:
Furry pets ( EX:Dog, Cats, Birds, Hamsters, Guinea Pigs, and Rabbits) are a common pet allergens that can trigger asthma symptoms in some people.

Pet hair and dander, especially cat hair, can fly in the air and be deposited on surfaces throughout the house and on items in the home..

Furry pets: How to avoid -reduce this trigger?

  • Keep furry pets out of bedrooms and off furniture

The hair and dander can cling to these items & expose people to the allergen in the home.

  • Wash furry pets & have them groomed frequently to remove the allergens as much as possible
  • Change clothing that has pets hair clinging on them before entering bedroom to avoid transfer of pet hair and dander from clothing to bedding, carpets etc.
  • Vacuum with a high efficiency filter (HEPA) and damp dust often to remove the allergens from the rooms.
  • Wash linens, blankets, curtains, and stuffed toys frequently to decrease allergens in room

targets.Name: Bed
Text:
Dust mites are found in beds & bedding.  Dust mites can be an allergy trigger for some people with asthma. Dust mites are so tiny they can’t be seen with the eye. They live in items made of thick fibers, such as bedding, carpets pillow, sofa, rugs and stuffed toys. 

Dust mites live and multiply in high humidity.

Dust mites:How to avoid -reduce this trigger ?

  • Cover mattress, box spring and pillows, with allergy-proof zippered covers.
  • Wash and dry all bedding on high heat at every week
  • Keep humidity level in home under 50%. 
  • Humidity levels can be measures by hygrometers which you can buy at a local hardware store or online for low cost.
This is a dresser. It is not an asthma trigger. Keep looking!
This is a dresser. It is not an asthma trigger. Keep looking!

targets.Name: Dust
Text:
House dust is a common allergy trigger for some people with asthma.

Dust can cause asthma symptoms or make asthma get worse.

House dust contains many tiny particles, some of which can be from pollen, mold,

pet dander & hair, dust mites, and pests.

Vacuum cleaners contain dust particles and can spread the dust.around a room or in the air.

House dust: How to avoid -reduce this trigger ?

  • •             Vacuum when the person with asthma is NOT at home because dust from vacuuming can be spread back into the air.
  • •             Use a vacuum cleaner with a high efficiency filter (HEPA filter vacuum) on carpet and fabric-covered furniture to reduce dust build-up and reduce the amount of dust coming out of the vacuum.
  • •             Be careful when emptying the dirt from the vacuum cleaner to avoid the collected dust spreading in the air.
  • •             Central heating and air conditioning systems may help control dust, change filters often.
  • •             Wipe away dust on all surfaces with a damp cloth and vacuum once a week.
  • •             Reduce clutter to help reduce dust.
  • •     Consider using a HEPA air purifier if airborne dust is a problem.                (AVOID IONIC & OZONE PRODUCING TYPES)

targets.Name: StuffedAnimals
Text:
Dust mites are found in stuffed toys. 

Dust mites can be an allergy trigger for some people with asthma.

 Dust mites are so tiny they can’t be seen with the eye.

They live in items made of thick fibers, such as bedding, carpets pillow, sofa, rugs and stuffed toys. 

Dust mites live and multiply in high humidity.

Dust mites in stuffed toys. How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

· Avoid use of, or limit (suggest less than 3) stuffed toys in home.

· No stuffed toy should be kept on the child’s bed.

· Use only washable stuffed toys and wash and dry these weekly, you can place them in a plastic bag & freeze them overnight too.

· Store washable stuffed toys in an airtight container out of the child’s bedroom

  • Keep humidity level in home under 50%. Humidity levels can be measured by hygrometers which you can buy at a local store or online for a low cost.

targets.Name: Perfume
Text:
Aerosol Sprays and strong scents (like perfume, hairspray, and cleaning products) can be an inhaled irritant and trigger asthma symptoms for some people with asthma. 

           

 

 Aerosol sprays like perfume (A possible inhaled irritant):How to avoid -reduce this trigger ?

•             Avoid using aerosol sprays indoors

•             Avoid use of products that are heavily scented

•             Air out a room where sprays were used

Pollens blowing in from outdoors can be sources of allergens and may trigger asthma symptoms in some people.  

They can be in the air, outdoors as well as indoors, they can land on household surfaces, car interiors and car exteriors

Pollens: How to avoid -reduce this trigger ?

•             Keep windows closed especially during high pollen days.

Pay attention to pollen levels. Check online, TV or sign up for weather & pollen alerts

•             Do not dry laundry outdoors during high pollen hours

•             Limit time spent outdoors on high pollen days and times. Remove clothing worn outdoors before sitting or lying on indoor furniture & bedroom areas, shower before going to bed.  

•             Wipe away dust on all surfaces with a damp cloth and vacuum once a week. Clean curtains, window treatments, and bedding often dust may contain pollens.

•             Use a vacuum cleaner with a high efficiency filter (HEPA filter vacuum) to clean                       pollen dust

•             Use window filters, or air conditioning, to filter out pollen in the air                                      Hepa filter air purifiers may help reduce airborne pollens                                                                  (AVOID IONIC & OZONE PRODUCING TYPES)
targets.Name: PollenCloud

Text:
Dust mites are found in rugs and carpeting. 

Dust mites can be an allergy trigger for some people with asthma.

Dust mites are so tiny they can’t be seen with the eye.

They live in items made of thick fibers, such as bedding, carpets pillow, sofa, rugs and stuffed toys. 

Dust mites thrive and multiply in high humidity.

Dust mites: How to avoid - reduce this trigger ?

  •  Remove rugs from the home
  • Replace rugs with tile or wood that can be damp mopped often
  • If you can’t take out the rugs, use a vacuum cleaner with a high efficiency filter (HEPA). Vacuum often
  • Keep humidity level in home under 50%. Humidity levels can be measured by hygrometers which you can buy at a local store or online for a low cost
targets.Name: Carpet

Text: This is an alarm clock. It is not an asthma trigger. You're getting warmer, though!

targets.Name: Clock

Text:
House dust is a common allergy trigger for some people with asthma and can cause asthma symptoms or make asthma get worse.

House dust contains many tiny particles, some of which can be from pollen, mold, pet dander, hair, dust mites, and pests.

House dust can be found on many surfaces and objects. Vacuum cleaners contain dust particles and can spread the dust. 

House dust:  How to avoid-reduce this trigger:

•             Vacuum when the person with asthma is NOT at home because dust from vacuuming can be spread back into the air.

•             Use a vacuum cleaner with a high efficiency filter (HEPA filter vacuum) on carpet and fabric-covered furniture to reduce dust build-up and reduce the amount of dust coming out of the vacuum.

•             Be careful when emptying the dirt from the vacuum cleaner to avoid the collected dust spreading in the air.

•             Central heating and air conditioning systems may help control dust, change filters often.

•           Reduce clutter to help reduce dust.and Wipe away dust on all surfaces with a damp cloth and vacuum once a week.             

•             Consider using a HEPA air purifier if airborne dust is a problem.     (AVOID IONIC & OZONE PRODUCING TYPES)

targets.Name: Hairbrush

Text: Welcome to the Trigger House - We invite you to visit each room in the house. This is meant to be fun and interactive. Each room is an example of what may be found in a home. Each room is set up to have some examples of things a person with asthma may be exposed to each day in their home or other places. Triggers are of two types: Allergens -these are things that may cause allergy symptoms for a person with asthma, and Irritants-these are things that can irritate the airways and cause asthma to worsen. Triggers are things that can cause or “trigger asthma symptoms for some people. The triggers can be in the air, on surfaces or within items. They can be breathed in and cause a reaction or problem in a person’s nose, throat, and lungs that cause them to have asthma symptoms. If a person with asthma lives with triggers that cause asthma symptoms, this can also cause their asthma to be not well controlled. This can affect the person’s ability to do normal activities, to not sleep well and can cause an asthma exacerbation also known as an Attack.
Phase 2
